title: Optimization
text: Exact algorithms class algorithms guarantee optimality (. S. L. Rodrigues & Gaston, 2002; Underhill, 1994). many different algorithms classified exact algorithms, including branch bound algorithm (Land & Doig, 1960), branch cut algorithm (Padberg & Giovanni, 1991), simplex algorithm (Dantzig, 1951), interior point algorithm (Dikin, 1967). Broadly speaking, exact algorithms can solve various types optimization problems. example, simplex algorithm can solve linear optimization problems contain continuous decision variables (termed “linear programming problems”). Additionally, branch bound algorithm can solve linear optimization problems contain integer decision variables (termed “integer programming problems”) contain integer continuous decision variables (termed “mixed integer programming problems”). algorithms applied many different tasks, facility location (Canel & Khumawala, 1996), job scheduling (Beaumont, 1997), route optimization (Schouwenaars et al., 2001). also becoming increasingly popular conservation planning (Hanson et al., 2019; . S. Rodrigues et al., 2000; Schuster et al., 2020). Work tool uses exact algorithms generate prioritizations. achieve , formulates conservation planning problems using minimum set (. S. Rodrigues et al., 2000) minimum shortfall (Jung et al., 2021) reserve selection problems (depending whether budget specified ) interfaces external optimization software solve problems (termed “exact algorithm solvers”). Currently, Work tool can use Gurobi CBC exact algorithm solvers (note Gurobi publicly available available advanced user access). Broadly speaking, solvers often support multiple different algorithms (e.g., might support simplex algorithm branch bound algorithm) can applied wide variety optimization problems. example, Gurobi software supports many different algorithms, including branch bound algorithm, barrier algorithm, interior point algorithm various simplex algorithms (see https://www.gurobi.com/). Additionally, exact algorithm solvers may also use heuristic algorithms – class iterative algorithms guarantee optimality – conjunction algorithms augment optimization process (e.g., Achterberg & Berthold, 2007). may also apply presolve algorithms – class algorithms designed simplify reduce size optimization problems – speedup subsequent optimization process (Achterberg et al., 2020). what: Advantages and disadvantages of exact algorithm solvers
title: Optimization
text: numerous advantages using exact algorithm solvers. key advantage exact algorithms provide guarantees solution quality. example, required, can solve problems optimality. words, can identify best possible solution mathematical optimization problem. real conservation decisions, can sometimes make large difference outcome (Schuster et al., 2020). Solving optimality can also reassure decision makers proposed solutions provide best possible outcomes, given data objectives entered system. Also, strict optimality required, can solve problems within pre-specified optimality gap (e.g., identify solution within 10% optimality). can useful solvers often able generate near optimal solutions much quickly strictly optimal solutions, whilst still providing guarantees solution quality. Although types algorithms can applied conservation problems (Ciarleglio et al., 2008; e.g., heuristic meta-heuristic algorithms; J. B. Kirkpatrick, 1983; S. Kirkpatrick et al., 1983; Nicholls & Margules, 1993), provide guarantees , , may require re-running optimization process tens thousands times verify solution quality (Ardron et al., 2010). Additionally, exact algorithm solvers can readily applied wide variety problems. Work tool uses exact algorithm solvers, can easily accommodate variety different conservation planning problems. instance, Work tool can used generate () prioritizations minimize cost whilst ensuring goals met (.e., “minimum set reserve selection problem”) (ii) prioritizations aim reach many goals possible, whilst ensuring total selected area exceed pre-specified budget (.e., “budget-limited reserve selection problem”). Furthermore, another advantage using exact algorithm solvers steadily increasing performance time (Achterberg & Wunderling, 2013). interfacing exact algorithm solvers, means Work tool leverages improvements newer versions solvers become available time. also several disadvantages using exact algorithm solvers. key disadvantage best performing exact algorithm solvers commercial software (e.g., Gurobi IBM CPLEX). Although open source exact algorithm solvers available (e.g., CBC, HiGHS, SYMPHONY), generally solve optimization problems quickly commercial solvers might able solve particularly large problems (Schuster et al., 2020). Commercial solvers often provide special free licenses academic use (e.g., Gurobi IBM CPLEX); however, commercial licenses may required use governmental, commercial, non-governmental organizations. , organizations may need carefully consider potential benefits costs associated using commercial solvers. Another disadvantage exact algorithms can much slower types algorithms. example, heuristic algorithms – guarantee solution quality – can generate near-optimal solutions optimization problems faster exact algorithms (Pressey et al., 1997; Zanakis & Evans, 1981). Indeed, Zonation decision support tool – powered iterative algorithms (Moilanen et al., 2022) – can likely solve budget-limited reserve selection problems faster Work tool. Finally, can challenging solve large-scale non-linear problems exact algorithms [e.g., problems include complex metrics connectivity; Keeley et al. (2021)]. Although means might able solve particularly complex mathematical optimization problems (Moilanen, 2008), exact algorithm solvers can applied many conservation planning problems (e.g., Hanson et al., 2019; . S. Rodrigues et al., 2000).

text: area_data numeric vector containing area planning unit. boundary_data Matrix::sparseMatrix() containing boundary data, NA. theme_data Matrix::sparseMatrix() containing theme data. weight_data Matrix::sparseMatrix() containing weight data. include_data Matrix::sparseMatrix() containing include data. exclude_data Matrix::sparseMatrix() containing exclude data. theme_settings data.frame containing theme settings. weight_settings data.frame containing weight settings. include_settings data.frame containing include settings. exclude_settings data.frame containing exclude settings. parameters list Parameter objects. overlap logical TRUE, excludes takes precedence includes. gap_1 numeric relative optimality gap value initial optimization. Defaults 0. gap_2 numeric relative optimality gap value spatial clustering. Defaults 0. boundary_gap numeric value used control level spatial clustering solution. Defaults 0.1. cache cachem::cache_mem() object used cache intermediate calculations. Defaults empty cache (effectively) cache used. time_limit_1 numeric time limit (seconds) initial optimization run. Defaults FALSE. id character identifier new result. try_gurobi logical value indicating Gurobi solver used generating solutions. Defaults FALSE.

title: Generate results using minimum set formulation — min_set_result
Generate results using minimum set formulation — min_set_result
code: # find data file paths f1 <- system.file(   "extdata", "projects", "sim_raster", "sim_raster_spatial.tif",   package = "wheretowork" ) f2 <- system.file(   "extdata",  "projects", "sim_raster", "sim_raster_attribute.csv.gz",   package = "wheretowork" ) f3 <- system.file(   "extdata",  "projects", "sim_raster", "sim_raster_boundary.csv.gz",   package = "wheretowork" )  # create new dataset d <- new_dataset(f1, f2, f3) # create variables v1 <- new_variable_from_auto(dataset = d, index = 1) v2 <- new_variable_from_auto(dataset = d, index = 2) v3 <- new_variable_from_auto(dataset = d, index = 3) v4 <- new_variable_from_auto(dataset = d, index = 4) v5 <- new_variable_from_auto(dataset = d, index = 5) v6 <- new_variable_from_auto(dataset = d, index = 6)  # create a weight using a variable w <- new_weight(   name = "Human Footprint Index", variable = v1,   factor = -90, status = FALSE, id = "W1" )  # create features using variables f1 <- new_feature(   name = "Possum", variable = v2,   goal = 0.2, status = FALSE, current = 0.5, id = "F1" ) f2 <- new_feature(   name = "Forests", variable = v3,   goal = 0.3, status = FALSE, current = 0.9, id = "F2" ) f3 <- new_feature(   name = "Shrubs", variable = v4,   goal = 0.6, status = TRUE, current = 0.4, id = "F3" )  # create themes using the features t1 <- new_theme("Species", f1, id = "T1") t2 <- new_theme("Ecoregions", list(f2, f3), id = "T2")  # create an included using a variable i <- new_include(   name = "Protected areas", variable = v5,   status = FALSE, id = "I1" )  # create an excluded using a variable e <- new_exclude(   name = "Expensive areas", variable = v6,   status = FALSE, id = "E1" )  # create parameters p1 <- new_parameter(name = "Spatial clustering") p2 <- new_parameter(name = "Optimality gap")  # create solution settings using the themes and weight ss <- new_solution_settings(   themes = list(t1, t2), weights = list(w), includes = list(i),   excludes = list(e), parameters = list(p1, p2) )  # create result x <- min_set_result(  id = "R1",  area_data = d$get_planning_unit_areas(),  boundary_data = d$get_boundary_data(),  theme_data = ss$get_theme_data(),  weight_data = ss$get_weight_data(),  include_data = ss$get_include_data(),  exclude_data = ss$get_exclude_data(),  theme_settings = ss$get_theme_settings(),  weight_settings = ss$get_weight_settings(),  include_settings = ss$get_include_settings(),  exclude_settings = ss$get_exclude_settings(),  parameters = ss$parameters,  overlap = TRUE,  gap_1 = p2$value * p2$status,  boundary_gap = p1$value * p1$status )  # print object print(x) #> Result object

create new dataset d <- new_dataset(f1, f2, f3)  # create variables v1 <- new_variable_from_auto(dataset = d, index = 1) v2 <- new_variable_from_auto(dataset = d, index = 2) v3 <- new_variable_from_auto(dataset = d, index = 3) v4 <- new_variable_from_auto(dataset = d, index = 4)  # code: # find data file paths f1 <- system.file(   "extdata", "projects", "sim_raster", "sim_raster_spatial.tif",   package = "wheretowork" ) f2 <- system.file(   "extdata",  "projects", "sim_raster", "sim_raster_attribute.csv.gz",   package = "wheretowork" ) f3 <- system.file(   "extdata",  "projects", "sim_raster", "sim_raster_boundary.csv.gz",   package = "wheretowork" )  # create new dataset d <- new_dataset(f1, f2, f3) # create variables v1 <- new_variable_from_auto(dataset = d, index = 1) v2 <- new_variable_from_auto(dataset = d, index = 2) v3 <- new_variable_from_auto(dataset = d, index = 3) v4 <- new_variable_from_auto(dataset = d, index = 4) v5 <- new_variable_from_auto(dataset = d, index = 5) v6 <- new_variable_from_auto(dataset = d, index = 6)  # create a weight using a variable w <- new_weight(   name = "Human Footprint Index", variable = v1,   factor = -90, status = FALSE, id = "W1" )  # create features using variables f1 <- new_feature(   name = "Possum", variable = v2,   goal = 0.2, status = FALSE, current = 0.5, id = "F1" ) f2 <- new_feature(   name = "Forests", variable = v3,   goal = 0.3, status = FALSE, current = 0.9, id = "F2" ) f3 <- new_feature(   name = "Shrubs", variable = v4,   goal = 0.6, status = TRUE, current = 0.4, id = "F3" )  # create themes using the features t1 <- new_theme("Species", f1, id = "T1") t2 <- new_theme("Ecoregions", list(f2, f3), id = "T2")  # create an include using a variable incl <- new_include(   name = "Protected areas", variable = v5,   status = FALSE, id = "I1" )  # create an exclude using a variable encl <- new_exclude(   name = "Urban areas", variable = v6,   status = FALSE, id = "E1" )  # create parameters p1 <- new_parameter(name = "Spatial clustering") p2 <- new_parameter(name = "Optimality gap")  # create solution settings using the themes and weight ss <- new_solution_settings(   themes = list(t1, t2), weights = list(w), includes = list(incl),   excludes = list(encl), parameters = list(p1, p2) )  # create solution values values <- sample(   c(0, 1), length(d$get_planning_unit_indices()), replace = TRUE )  # create object r <- new_result(   values = values,   area = 12,   perimeter = 10,   theme_coverage = calculate_coverage(values, ss$get_theme_data()),   weight_coverage = calculate_coverage(values, ss$get_weight_data()),   include_coverage = calculate_coverage(values, ss$get_include_data()),   exclude_coverage = calculate_coverage(values, ss$get_exclude_data()),   theme_settings = ss$get_theme_settings(),   weight_settings = ss$get_weight_settings(),   include_settings = ss$get_include_settings(),   exclude_settings = ss$get_exclude_settings(),   parameters = ss$parameters )  # print object print(r) #> Result object

title: New variable from metadata — new_variable_from_metadata

title: New variable from metadata — new_variable_from_metadata
text: argument metadata contain following elements: "index" character integer indicating field/layer data within dataset data. "units" character units values underlying data. "type" character indicating data contain continuous ("continuous") categorical ("categorical") values. "provenance" character indicating data source. (see new_provenance_from_source()). "colors" character vector containing colors visualization. "total" numeric sum values dataset. "min_value" numeric minimum value dataset. Required continuous data. "max_value" numeric maximum value dataset. Required continuous data. "values" numeric vector unique value dataset. Required categorical data. "labels" character vector unique labels manual legend. Required categorical data, manual legend.

Defaults TRUE. current numeric current proportion values held existing conservation areas (e.g. 0.1 = 10%). factor numeric initial factor value. Defaults 0. id character unique identifier. title: Run the Shiny Application — run_app
text: onStart function called app actually run. needed shinyAppObj, since shinyAppDir case, global.R file can used purpose. options Named options passed runApp call (can following: "port", "launch.browser", "host", "quiet", "display.mode" "test.mode"). can also specify width height parameters provide hint embedding environment ideal height/width app. enableBookmarking Can one "url", "server", "disable". default value, NULL, respect setting previous calls  enableBookmarking(). See enableBookmarking() information bookmarking app. uiPattern regular expression applied GET request determine whether ui used handle request. Note entire request path must match regular expression order match considered successful. ... arguments pass golem_opts. See ?golem::get_golem_options details.

title: Simulate data — simulate_data
text: x terra::rast() sf::st_sf() object use template. n integer number layers simulate. Defaults 1. scale numeric parameter control level spatial auto-correlation simulated data. Defaults 0.5. intensity numeric average value simulated data. Defaults 0. sd numeric standard deviation simulated data. Defaults 1. transform function transform values output simulation. Defaults identity() function values remain following transformation.

text: x list Theme, Weight, Include, Exclude objects. dataset Dataset object. path character file path save configuration file. name character name scenario. spatial_path character file path spatial data. attribute_path character file path attribute data. boundary_path character file path attribute data. mode character mode running application. title: Write project — write_project
code: # find data file paths  f1 <- system.file(    "extdata", "projects", "sim_raster", "sim_raster_spatial.tif",    package = "wheretowork"  )  f2 <- system.file(    "extdata", "projects", "sim_raster", "sim_raster_attribute.csv.gz",    package = "wheretowork"  )  f3 <- system.file(    "extdata", "projects", "sim_raster", "sim_raster_boundary.csv.gz",    package = "wheretowork"  )   # create new dataset  d <- new_dataset(f1, f2, f3)   # simulate themes and weights  th <- simulate_themes(d, 1, 1, 2)  w <- simulate_weights(d, 1)   # combine themes and weights into a list  l <- append(th, w)   # save project  write_project(    x = l,    name = "example",    dataset = d,    path = tempfile(),    spatial_path = tempfile(fileext = ".tif"),    attribute_path = tempfile(fileext = ".csv.gz"),    boundary_path = tempfile(fileext = ".csv.gz")  )

title: wheretowork 1.0.2
text: Multiple layer download bug fix, issue #391.

title: wheretowork 1.0.0
text: Boundary data required spatial clustering changed prioritizr 8.0.4 format. includes better approach rescaling data avoid numerical issues optimization. Earlier versions package recommended use scales::rescale() rescale data. Now use prioritizr::rescale_matrix() function rescale boundary length data. Work can still load older boundary data generated previous projects, however recommended new projects prep data prioritizr >= 8.0.4 wheretowork 1.0.0. renv.lock file includes application dependencies Imports, Depends LinksTo found within DESCRIPTION file. include Suggests packages needed development. reduces bloat deployment installing wheretowork data prep. steps contribute package development include cloning wheretowork, running renv::restore(), manually renv::install Suggests packages referencing correct version. Example renv::install(testthat@3.3.2.1.1). Gurobi CRAN package. Follow gurobi installation guide found prioritizr.net article: https://prioritizr.net/articles/gurobi_installation_guide.html.

title: wheretowork 1.0.0
text: Requires R version 4.4. Migrated raster package terra package. Updated CRAN package dependencies latest version August, 2024. Updated REMOTE leaflet package dependency latest version August, 2024. Added backwards compatibility boundary data. Removed leaflet.extras2::addHistory button. feature compatible Shiny >= 1.7.0 removed bundled copy fontawesome fontawesome package. Updated license agreement. Updated renv.lock file records application dependencies Imports, Depends LinksTo.

title: wheretowork 1.0.0
text: write_project function now includes wheretowork prioritizr package version number attribute.yaml. read_project function checks prioritizr version number exist < version 8.0.4. true, update_bm method called Dataset class update boundary data new format. Replaced pryr lobstr tracking memory usage. Removed readNamedRaster, function never called. Removed raster layer names .txt writeNamedRaster function. terra::writeRaster function default keeps layer names.
